channel.title: Homes on Svetha Venkatesh
channel.description: Recent content in Homes on Svetha Venkatesh

item.description: Biography Svetha Venkatesh is an ARC Australian Laureate Fellow, Alfred Deakin Professor and Co-Director of Applied Artificial Intelligence Institute (A2I2) at Deakin University. She was elected a Fellow of the International Association of Pattern Recognition in 2004 for contributions to formulation and extraction of semantics in multimedia data, and a Fellow of the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences and Engineering in 2006. In 2017, Professor Venkatesh was appointed an Australian Laureate Fellow, the highest individual award the Australian Research Council can bestow.

item.title: Selected Awards and Honours
item.description: 2018: Best Paper Award, Pacific Asia Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining, Melbourne, Australia 2018 Victorian Honour Roll of Women 2017 ARC Australian Laureate Fellowship 2017: PAKDD’17: Best Application paper 2016: ACML’16:Best Paper RunnerUp 2015: STEM Hero 2014: Best Paper Award, Pacific Asia Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining, Vietnam 2013: Excellence in International Education – Research Engagement , Victorian International Education Awards 2013 & 2012: Smart Technology Award, Geelong Chamber of Commerce - for Toby Playpad and identifying suicidal patients via machine learning 2011: WA Inventor of the Year, iiNet Award - for iCetana 2010: Broadband Innovation Award, Tech23 - for iCetana 2000: Best Paper Award, IEEE Pacific Rim Conference on Multimedia

item.title: Fellowship
item.description: 2006 - : Fellow, Australian Academy of Technological Sciences and Engineering (ATSE) 2004 - : Fellow, International Association of Pattern Recognition (IAPR) 1996 - 1997: Fellow, Institute of Advanced Study, Berlin

item.title: Research
item.description: Our methods are grounded in statistical machine learning and pattern recognition. In our research, we ask the following questions: What are the models that we must construct to be computationally scalable in big-data problems? How do we enhance the expressiveness of such models, what are the representations and can we develop appropriate inference and learning?
